RT @ttunguz: The Innovator's Solution for SaaS Startups - The Flywheel SaaS Company http://t.co/MUotpF0SVk
@mcannonbrookes @ttunguz an interesting question, for sure. Investors and "new" management often know only one way, and  lose patience.
@ttunguz @mcannonbrookes if there's no bottom-up adoption, then this shift might make sense. But that's a declining set of products.
@ttunguz atlassian, github, mailchimp come to mind. But there are others. You can tell when they don't talk about enterprise much.
@ttunguz lastly - if your inside team is only targeting $500k of productivity, then you need a lot more leverage!  $1M+ is more like it.
@ttunguz it's common to be sure, but it ruins a lot of very efficient GTM models in SaaS.
@ttunguz framing it as a pivot that companies make - turning away from the high volume deals - is describing the wrong way to do it, IMO.
@ttunguz so adding mid-market and enterprise deals is a skill that sales teams can develop. It's done best when the product evolves too.
@ttunguz early SaaS growth isn't about just selling to SMB - departmental enterprise and mid market teams buy the same way.
@ttunguz you know I love your work - but I have many points of disagreement with this post.
